results.title: For all practical purposes. Computer science. 5
results.creator_credit: COMAP, Chedd-Angier Productions and Joseph Blatt
results.brief_description: Moving picture show Computers can be used to produce a remarkable range of graphics and this program looks at how these graphics are produced. Pixels are the fundamental unit of computer images, and nothing can be drawn smaller than a pixel, which means that lines can be jagged rather than smooth. We look at anti-aliasing techniques which solve this and algorithms which solve the problems of limited time and memory. We then look at three programs from Symbolics Inc. - “Geometry” which creates 3D objects, “Dynamics” which moves them and “Render” which makes them realistic. Demonstrated techniques include splining, translation, scaling, rotation, texture mapping and opacity.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Computer science. 4
results.creator_credit: COMAP, Chedd-Angier Productions and Lance Wisniewski
results.brief_description: Creating codes Developing the concept of binary codes, introduced in the previous episode, this program looks at some of the different codes which can be devised, including ASCII which is a 7 bit code, the Laplacian pyramid which is used for encoding pictorial images and the Hamming code, which enables computers to overcome random errors.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Computer science. 3
results.brief_description: Counting by twos Sol Garfunkel explains the binary system and how it enables computers to function. He demonstrates the system through the digital recording of music and player piano rolls and goes on to explain booleian logic.
results.description: Counting by twos Sol Garfunkel explains the binary system and how it enables computers to function. He demonstrates the system through the digital recording of music and player piano rolls and goes on to explain booleian logic.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Computer science. 2
results.brief_description: In this program Sol Garfunkel explains and defines algorithms, which are a sequence of steps or directions to accomplish a goal, and which lie at the root of programming. Algorithms must be well-defined, effective, must produce an output and must terminate in a reasonable period of time. Examples used to demonstrate are making a peanut butter and jam sandwich and finding the best route to work. The program concludes with a basic task of a computer - sorting and two forms of sorting - insertion sorting and merge sorting.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Computer science. 1
results.brief_description: Overview In this first episode of the computer science module, Sol Garfunkel conveys his enthusiasm for mathematics as a living, evolving science which is closely related to the real world, by asking the fundamental question “What is mathematics”. Concluding that mathematics is the relationship between proof and truth he then launches into a history of modern mathematics, and therefore of computers. He touches on the work of David Hilbert which included symbolic logic and self-referential paradoxes, Kurt Godel and his theorem which found a true statement that was unprovable, and Alan Turing’s idea of machines. He continues with John von Neumann’s early work in linking, logic, proof and computation and concludes with a look at minimal surfaces, normal maps and the use of the computer as an experimental tool.

results.title: For a lost soldier = Voor een verloren soldaat
results.creator_credit: Sigma Film Productions, Matthijs van Heijningen and Roeland Kerbosch
results.brief_description: Forty years after the fact, choreographer Jeroen Boman (Jeroen Krabbe), recalls his childhood experiences as an adolescent in wartime Holland. Evacuated from Amsterdam to a country village, young Jeroen (Maarten Smit) is troubled by the isolation from his family and the sexual curiosity of the girls and boys around him. Once the Allied Forces move into the village, Jeroen enters into a tender relationship with Canadian soldier, Walt (Andrew Kelley). Never stooping to sensationalism, this gay ‘coming of age’ film is delicately handled and beautifully written. From the novel by Rudi Van Dantzig. In Dutch with English subtitles.

results.title: For a few dollars more = Per Qualche dollari in piu [Widescreen] (S)
results.creator_credit: Produzioni Europee Associati, Arturo Gonzales, Constantin Film, Alberto Grimaldi and Sergio Leone
results.brief_description: This follow-up to Sergio Leone’s “A Fistful of Dollars” brings back Clint Eastwood as the serape-clad, cigar-chewing Man With No Name. Engaged in an ongoing battle with bounty hunter Col. Douglas Mortimer, Eastwood joins forces with his enemy to capture the homicidal bandit El Indio. Musical score by Ennio Morricone. Cast includes Clint Eastwood, Lee Van Cleef, Gian Marian Volonte and Klaus Kinski.

results.title: Footy for kids
results.brief_description: Designed for coaches of junior footballers. Highlights the sequential stages of skill development, the aim of practice sessions for junior players, the format of practice sessions and the principles of skill teaching.

results.title: Footy chicks
results.creator_credit: Australian Film Commission, Red Ithaka Productions, SBS Independent, Michaela Perske and Rebecca Barry
results.brief_description: Many Australians love their football; many Australian women also desire the men who play it. Michaela Perske and Rebecca Barry have made a hard-hitting documentary that uses a combination of interviews, observational filming and stylised re-enactments to examine some of the interactions between football players and “Footy Chicks”. In the early 21st century, Australia saw a number of allegations of sexual assaults on women made against football players and clubs from both the Rugby League and AFL codes. Against this background, “Footy Chicks” explores the gender and sexual power relationships, and the attitudes of both players and women to the fun and the dangers involved in the sexual culture of Australian football. As well as the players and “footy chicks” who speak for themselves, interviewees include Kath Haines from Footy Fans Against Sexual Assault; Dr Clifton Evers, Lecturer in Gender Studies; Dr Catharine Lumby, Associate Professor Media Studies, and Karen Willis from the New South Wales Rape Crisis Centre.

results.title: Footscray 1911
results.brief_description: Scenes of Footscray around 1911. Shows street scenes, transport, recreation and clothing. Recognizable scenes include Nicholson Street and Forges Store. Footscray Railway Station and Federal Hall.
